awd_titl_txt: The Relationship Between Grain Structure and Deformation Behavior to the Fracture Mechanism in High Strength-High Ductility Combination Nanostructured Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract 

The proposed research concerning the next generation of high strength materials is envisaged to extend the state-of-art of processing of high strength-high ductility alloys with superior formability. The unlocking of fracture mechanisms underlying high strength-high ductility combination will be a major breakthrough in guiding the development of strong and ductile metallic materials. The ultimate objective is to determine guidelines to pioneer a new frontier of high strength-high ductility materials for light and efficient solutions involving energy absorption and formability.  Furthermore, new techniques will be developed to understand material behavior that will be applicable to other metallic systems. The high strength-high ductility combination of nanograined materials will allow for thinner sections or components, which will lead to fuel economy in the transportation sector.

Technical Abstract

The research objective of the award is to determine the fundamental criteria in obtaining high strength - high ductility combination in metals with grain size in the nanometer range. The criteria will be elucidated by conducting controlled mechanical deformation experiments in conjunction with the study of deformed region via microscopy tools. Experiments will involve increasing the stability of the principal constituent with decrease in grain size. The criteria will define if the stability of the principal constituent of the metallic material is responsible in governing the ductility and delayed fracture of high strength metallic materials. The changes in deformation behavior will be studied as a function of grain size from nanograin regime to conventional micrometer regime. Physical models with predictive capabilities for a wide range of material systems based on the inter-relationship between grain size, deformation process and fracture mechanisms will be developed.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at El Paso
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT EL PASO

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at El Paso

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The phase reversion concept developed in the principal investigator?s laboratory was successfully used to obtain a wide spectrum of grain size from the nanograined to the coarse-grained regime using a single set of processing parameters. The concept enabled fundamental insights to be obtained into the effects of grain size from the nanograined to the coarse-grained regime on the fracture behavior in the austenitic alloy. This led to unlocking of relationship between the deformation behavior and fracture process in high strength-high ductility combination nanograined alloy, which was a major breakthrough in guiding the development of strong and ductile nanocrystalline materials. The change in the deformation behavior from strain-induced martensite in the coarse-grained structure to nanoscale twinning in the nanograined structure governed the fracture mechanism with line-up of voids along the striations in the nanograined structure and microvoid coalescence in the coarse-grained structure at similar elongation, and was related to the grain size effect. Furthermore, the studies conducted from the nanograined to the coarse-grained regime provided an unambiguous understanding and unraveled the influence of deformation twinning in nanograined alloys on the fracture mechanism. A mechanistic contribution of twinning to quasi-static crack growth process in conjunction with a theoretical model emerged for the nanograined alloys, which was radically different from the conventional coarse-grained alloy. The discovery of the ?grain structure-deformation behavior? and relationship to fracture mechanism was considered fundamentally important for designing material structures with optimum mechanical properties.

Broader Impacts: The impact of research was far reaching because of the need to pioneer a new frontier of high strength-high ductility materials for light and efficient solutions involving energy absorption and formability. The high elongation and work hardening of nanograined alloys was considered important while adopting ?forming-to-strength? approach, where the material attains its target strength level by controlled work hardening during the forming process. The research directly impacted twinning-induced plasticity and low density steels that are being developed.

        The proposed research provided a unique experience to students at the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), a minority institution, in terms of the development of nanoscale deformation techniques. The physical metallurgy concepts were introduced to nanograined materials, impacting the metals-related nanotechnology research at UTEP. Furthermore, the creative nature of research was integrated into the curriculum.

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2022
Modified by: Devesh Misra
